instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00687: What is 820-00687? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00687</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no ppdcin.
threads.message:
hi, this macbook came in, dead, but no 20v yet, so i dont jump to cpu bad conclusion ( yeah in the future maybe, but customer wants data )
there's no 5v at ammeter.
ppdcin at r7020and <RESISTOR>R7010</RESISTOR> is 0v.
whole board is pristine, am I looking at some kind of bad mosfet here ?
pointer is appreciated... thanks..
ppdcin isnt shorted.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00687</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no ppdcin.
threads.message: pin 1 of j9600 <SIGNAL>USBC_XA_CC1</SIGNAL> is shorted at 25 ohm, should be bad <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> right ?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00687</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no ppdcin.
threads.message:
Very likely.
CC1/2 lines are used by charger to detect the MLB.
Is the hardware way to make it sends out 5V in VBUS.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00687</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no ppdcin.
threads.message:
okayy thankss sir.
<CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> is the culprit, solved.. (y)
